entry.title: Girl One
entry.content:
I finished reading Girl One by Sara Flannery Murphy.

A little bit sci-fi, a little bit adventure thriller. An entertaining easy read.

entry.title: The Talmud
entry.content:
I finished reading The Talmud by Barry Scott Wimpfheimer.

I’ve enjoyed a lot of the Biographies of Ancient Books series but this one left me flat.

entry.title: The Testament of Mary
entry.content:
I finished reading The Testament of Mary by Colm Toibin.

A beautiful first-person narrative that considers Jesus’ life from a different-than-usual perspective.

entry.title: Starter Villain
entry.content:
I finished reading Starter Villain by John Scalzi.

Ridiculous, cheesy fun.

entry.title: Blackouts
entry.content:
I finished reading Blackouts by Justin Torres.

Framed as an oral history of an old, dying gay man telling his story to a younger gay man. Mesmerizing.

entry.title: The Phenomenon of Man
entry.content:
I finished reading The Phenomenon of Man by Pierre Teilhard de Chardin.

A whole lot to unpack here as Teilhard sees the vision of an evolutionary universe powered by love.

entry.title: Transitions
entry.content:
I finished reading Transitions by William Bridges.

As with all self help books, you’ve gotta eat the meat and spit out the bones. Some good stuff here particularly about what he terms the “Neutral Zone” between the old thing and the new thing.

entry.title: The Fifth Season
entry.content:
I finished reading The Fifth Season by N. K. Jemisin.

Fantastic world building and beautiful writing. Deserving of the awards it won.

entry.title: Quantum Reality
entry.content:
I finished reading Quantum Reality by Nick Herbert.

A little bit dated at this point, but a very digestible introduction to quantum theory.

entry.title: The Left Hand of Darkness
entry.content:
I finished reading The Left Hand of Darkness by Ursula K. Le Guin.

I get what LeGuin was going for, but this one just didn’t land for me. Plenty of idea, not enough story.

entry.title: On the Origin of Time
entry.content:
I finished reading On the Origin of Time by Thomas Hertog.

Hertog studied quantum physics under Stephen Hawking and here overviews Hawking’s progression of thought in quantum physics, ending in a remarkable position regaining the importance of the human perspective within these theories. You don’t expect to get to the last chapter of a book like this and have it start quoting Hannah Arendt, and yet this one did. Thoughtful, not overly simplified but simplified enough for nerdy laymen like me to be able to wade through it… quite a book.

entry.title: Red Queen
entry.content:
I finished reading Red Queen by Juan GÃ³mez-Jurado.

Entertaining detective novel. Nothing deep, but a nice palate cleanser.

entry.title: The Odyssey
entry.content:
I finished reading The Odyssey by Homer.

Emily Wilson’s translation of The Odyssey pulled me in in a way that other translations have failed to grab me. Obviously an epic story, but her translation choices made it come alive in reading.

entry.title: Average Jones
entry.content:
I finished reading Average Jones by Samuel Adams.

Short detective stories in the vein of Sherlock Holmes, but set in early 20th-century America. They’re fine, but mostly serve to remind you just how good Sir Arthur Conan Doyle’s stories were by comparison.

entry.title: Translation State
entry.content:
I finished reading Translation State by Ann Leckie.

A brilliant examination of gender and personhood wrapped up in an adventure story. Really enjoyed this one.

entry.title: The Ultimate Quest
entry.content:
I finished reading The Ultimate Quest by Jordan Haynie Ware.

A short handbook intro to the Episcopal Church. The subtitle “A Geek’s Guide to The Episcopal Church” tells you where it’s going, and it goes HARD. Some of the geek references were helpful; some of them seemed pretty over-the-top, but you can’t deny the author’s commitment to the bit. Still, it’s a book I might hand to my college aged kid if they had any interested in attending.

entry.title: The Book of Job - a Biography
entry.content:
I finished reading The Book of Job - a Biography by Mark Larrimore.

I’ve been a fan of other books in this Lives of Great Religious Books series, but this one didn’t really do it for me. Less about how Job came about and more about how it has been interpreted through time. Which isn’t bad… just wasn’t what I was looking for.

entry.title: Until the End of Time
entry.content:
I finished reading Until the End of Time by Brian Greene.

The bits where Greene is explaining physics are wonderful. The bits where he tries to theorize about how the effects of physics manifest in things like meaning and belief are pretty weak.

entry.title: Being Heumann
entry.content:
I finished reading Being Heumann by Judith Heumann.

A brisk, moving memoir of a leader in the American movement for disabled rights. I had no idea that the Americans with Disabilities Act wasn’t passed until I was in high school.

entry.title: How Far the Light Reaches
entry.content:
I finished reading How Far the Light Reaches by Sabrina Imbler.

A short memoir of sorts, fascinating stuff, beautifully written.
